eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: SpeedRestrictions
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Limit the maximum movement and rotation speed of an object from forces or the physics behavior.
description: Limit the maximum movement and rotation speed of an object from forces or the physics behavior.
How to use:
- Add the behavior that matches the method used to move the object (forces or physics)
- Set the maximum speed value in the behavior properties
Tips:
- This only affects movement caused by forces or physics behavior
- This may not affect movement caused by other behaviors (platformer, top-down, draggable, etc)

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: ScreenWrap
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Teleport object when it moves off the screen and immediately appear on the opposite side while maintaining speed and trajectory.
description: The teleport happens when the center point of the object crosses a border (this can be adjusted with an offset).
By default, the borders of the wrapping area match the screen size, but they can alo be changed.
The Asteroid-like example uses this extension ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://space-asteroid)).

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Silver-Streak, @Bouh, Tristan Rhodes
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: IsOnScreen
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: This adds a condition to detect if an object is on screen based off its current layer.
description: This extension adds conditions to check if an object is located within the visible portion of its layer's camera. The condition also allows for specifying padding to the virtual screen border.
Note that this does not take into account any object visibility, such as being hidden or 0 opacity, but can be combined with those existing conditions.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description:
This behavior provides a condition to check if the object is located within the visible portion of its layer's camera. The condition also allows for specifying padding to the virtual screen border.
Note that object visibility, such as being hidden or 0 opacity, is not considered (but you can use those existing conditions in addition to this behavior).
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: InOnScreen

eventsFunctions.description: Checks if an object position is within the viewport of its layer.
eventsFunctions.name: IsOnScreen

inlineCode: Get the object layer, convert the position from this layer to the screen coordinates.
Get the point on each side on the object on screen, and compare with the screen area.
This way even if the camera has a rotation or custom scale the object is always compared to the screen area.
// Get the layer of the object.
// Get the aabb of the object on his layer.
// Get the layer to convert the coordinates of the AABB to the screen coordinates
// Get the points on each side of the object on screen.
const posLeftObjectOnScreen = Math.min(topLeft[0], topRight[0], bottomLeft[0], bottomRight[0]);
const posRightObjectOnScreen = Math.max(topLeft[0], topRight[0], bottomLeft[0], bottomRight[0]);
const posUpObjectOnScreen = Math.min(topLeft[1], topRight[1], bottomLeft[1], bottomRight[1]);
const posDownObjectOnScreen = Math.max(topLeft[1], topRight[1], bottomLeft[1], bottomRight[1]);

parameters.longDescription: Number of pixels to pad the screen border. Zero by default. A negative value goes inside the screen, a positive value go outside.
parameters.name: Padding

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Flash
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Make an object flash visibility (blink), color tint, object effect, or opacity (fade).
description: Make an object flash for a period of time so that it alternates between two different states.
Includes the ability to flash visibility (blink), color tint, object effect, or opacity (fade).
After adding a behavior to an object, you **trigger the effect** by using the **Flash action**.
This can be used to:
- Let players know they are invincible after being hit
- Catch player attention on the interface (for instance a "press start" text)

eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Make an object rain from a selected direction or a selected object.
description: - User can select the rain object.
- User can select to rain object from a selected direction.
- User can set condition to check if the rain object collides with another object.
- User can set action to Stop/Start the rain object.
- User can select object2 to rain object from it on a selected direction.
- User can set an action to stop rain object from moving.
- User can set the rain intensity.
- User can set the rain angle.
- User can set the rain animation after the collision.
- User have the option (On/Off) to delete the rain objects when it's out of screen.

objects.string: It displays the value when it changes.

content.text: It displays the value when it changes.

events.comment: This allows to detect a change of "intial value" on hot reload.
Create the child-object instances.
Create the label that is displayed over the thumb.
Pass the configuration to the behavior.

Children instances must be resized when the parent size change:
- background is resized to take the full dimensions of the parent
- the label is put back at the center of the bar

The scale is set back to 1 because it means that the parent instance has the same dimensions as the union of its children instances.

parameters: max(Background.BoundingBoxRight(), max(Label.BoundingBoxRight(), Thumb.BoundingBoxRight())) - min(Background.BoundingBoxLeft(), min(Label.BoundingBoxLeft(), Thumb.BoundingBoxLeft()))
max(Background.BoundingBoxBottom(), max(Label.BoundingBoxBottom(), Thumb.BoundingBoxBottom())) - min(Background.BoundingBoxTop(), min(Label.BoundingBoxTop(), Thumb.BoundingBoxTop()))

events.comment: The parent size is not defined in onCreate so it needs to be done here.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Boomerang
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Throw an object that returns to the thrower like a boomerang.
description: Throw an object that returns to the thrower after a length of time, or when an action is used to return it.
How to throw a boomerang:
- Create a bomerang object that has this behavior
- Use one of the "Throw boomerang..." actions
- Run the "Track location of thrower" action every frame so the boomerang returns correctly
Tips:
- If you want the boomerang to bounce off objects, check for collisions and then use the action "Send boomerang back to thrower"

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Bouh
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Gamepads
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Add support for gamepads (or other controllers) to your game, giving access to information such as button presses, axis positions, trigger pressure, etc...
description: Add support for gamepads (or other controllers).
It gives access to:
- button presses
- axis positions and force
- trigger pressure
- configurable deadzone
- vibration
- automatic mappers for platformer characters and top-down movement
The Bomberman-like example handles 4 players with gamepads ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://goose-bomberman)).

eventsFunctionsExtensions.previewIconUrl: https://resources.gdevelop-app.com/assets/Icons/Line Hero Pack/Master/SVG/Sports and Fitness/Sports and Fitness_training_running_run.svg
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Let platformer characters: air jump, wall jump wall sliding, coyote time and dashing.
description: This extension provides behaviors to:
* Jump in mid-air
* Jump and slide against walls
* Dash horizontally
* Dash toward the floor

* Do coyote time, also known as "ledge tolerance". It lets players jumping even after their character is no longer touching the ground for a given amount of time. It aims to give players a feeling of control and reduce frustration.
An example allows to check it out ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://platformer-moves)).

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Let platformer characters jump shortly after leaving a platform and also jump in mid-air.

events.comment: Avoid any side effect if the feature is not used.
The timeframe is starting.
The timeframe is missed.
Coyote jump
The new value will be used next frame.
While in the coyote jump frame, the Object is treated as being on the floor. No air jump can happen.
When the object fall, it doesn't jump but air jumps must be allowed

The order of these events is important because the idle state is:
on the floor and jump key released but the 1st jump must not count.
Reset air jump counter.
Allow air jumps.
Coyote time was disabled, so WasInTheAir may not have been updated for a long time.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: SmoothCamera
eventsFunctionsExtensions.previewIconUrl: https://resources.gdevelop-app.com/assets/Icons/Line Hero Pack/Master/SVG/Computers and Hardware/Computers and Hardware_camcoder_gopro_go_pro_camera.svg
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Smoothly scroll to follow an object.
description: The camera follows an object according to:
- a frame rate independent catch-up speed to make the scrolling from smooth to strong
- a maximum speed to do linear following ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://platformer-with-tilemap)) or slow down the camera when teleporting the object
- a follow-free zone to avoid scrolling on small movements
- an offset to see further in one direction
- an extra delay and catch-up speed to give an impression of speed (useful for dash)
- position forecasting and delay to simulate a cameraman response time
A platformer dedicated behavior allows to switch of settings when the character is in air or on the floor. This can be used to stabilize the camera when jumping.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Smoothly scroll to follow an object.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: SmoothCamera

events.comment:
Delaying and forecasting can be used at the same time.
Forecasting only use the positions that are older than the one used for delaying.
The behavior uses a position history that is split in 2 arrays:
- one for delaying the position (from TimeFromStart to TimeFromStart - CamearDelay)
- one for forecasting the position (from TimeFromStart - CamearDelay to TimeFromStart - CamearDelay - ForecastHistoryDuration

At each frame, the camera must catchup the target by a given ratio (speed)
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - 1) - targetX) * speed

The frame rate must not impact on the catch-up speed, we don't want a speed in ratio per frame but a speed ratio per second, like this:
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - 1s) - targetX) * speed

Ok, but we still need to process each frame, we can use a exponent for this:
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - timeDelta) - targetX) * speed^timeDelta
cameraX(t) = targetX + (cameraX(t - timeDelta) - targetX) * exp(timeDelta * ln(speed))

pow is probably more efficient than precalculated log if the speed is changed continuously but this might be rare enough.

eventsFunctions.name: UpdateForecastedPosition

events.comment:
Simple linear regression
y = A * x + B

A = Covariance / VarianceX
B = MeanY - A * MeanX

Note than we could use only one position every N positions to reduce the process time,
but if we really need efficient process JavaScript and circular queues are a must.

VarianceX = sum((X[i] - MeanX))
VarianceY = sum((Y[i] - MeanY))
Covariance = sum((X[i] - MeanX) * (Y[i] - MeanY))

y = A * x + B

A = Covariance / VarianceX
B = MeanY - A * MeanX
Axis permutation to avoid a ratio between 2 numbers near 0.
Permute back axis

eventsFunctions.description: Project history ends position to have the vector on the line from linear regression. This function is only called by UpdateForecastedPosition.
eventsFunctions.name: ProjectHistoryEnds
eventsFunctions.sentence: Project history oldest: _PARAM2_;_PARAM3_ and newest position: _PARAM4_;_PARAM5_ of _PARAM0_

events.comment:
Perpendicular line:
pA = -1/a; 
pB = -pA * x + y

Intersection:
/ ProjectedY = a * ProjectedX + b
\ ProjectedY = pA * ProjectedX + b

Solution that is cleaned out from indeterminism (like 0 / 0 or infinity / infinity):
ProjectedX= (x + (y - b) * a) / (a + 1)
ProjectedY = y + (x * a - y + b) / (a + 1)

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: AdvancedProjectile
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Control how a projectile moves including speed, acceleration, distance, and lifetime.
description: Control how a projectile moves including speed, acceleration, distance, and lifetime.
Tips:
- To simulate a rocket, use a starting speed of 0 and a positive acceleration (max speed may also be used)
- To simulate a hand grenade, use a high starting speed, a negative acceleration, and a non-zero lifetime
- If the object is not moving, acceleration will be towards the direction it is facing
- If the object is moving, acceleration will be in the direction the object is moving

eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Turn any object into a cursor.

Breaking change of the version 2.0.0:

- The button behavior has been removed. The button object can be used instead. Some ready to use buttons can be downloaded from the [Buttons pack](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?initial-dialog=asset-store&asset-pack=menu-buttons-menu-buttons) of the asset store.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: A button that can be customized.

events.comment:
Create one background instance for of each state.
Only the instance for the current state is shown.
Place the label over the backgrounds.
Show the right background accordingly to the new state.

Children instances must be resized when the button size change:
- backgrounds for each state are resized to take the full dimensions of the button
- the label is put back at the center of the button

The scale is set back to 1 because it means that the parent instance has the same dimensions as the union of its children instances.
